docs.snippet: George Duning, an Oscar-nominated composer who wrote music for films and television, died on Sunday at Alavarado Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 92.    Mr. Duning received Academy Award nominations for five film scores he wrote for Columbia Pictur...
docs.lead_paragraph: George Duning, an Oscar-nominated composer who wrote music for films and television, died on Sunday at Alavarado Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 92. Mr. Duning received Academy Award nominations for five film scores he wrote for Columbia Pictures, where he worked from 1947 to 1962: ''Jolson Sings Again'' (1949), ''No Sad Songs for Me'' (1950), ''From Here to Eternity'' (1953), ''Picnic'' (1955) and ''The Eddy Duchin Story'' (1956).
docs.abstract: George Duning, Oscar-nominated composer who wrote music for films and television, dies at age 92 (S)

docs.snippet: His father was in and out of prison. His mother, evicted from her own home, sent him and his brother to live with an uncle in a dilapidated house here, just north of Flint. There, he did not even have his own bed and fell asleep in a place that ne...
docs.lead_paragraph: His father was in and out of prison. His mother, evicted from her own home, sent him and his brother to live with an uncle in a dilapidated house here, just north of Flint. There, he did not even have his own bed and fell asleep in a place that neighbors say was filled with noise, drugs and guns. And on Tuesday, the police say, the 6-year-old got his hands on one of those guns, stuffed it in his pants pocket and went off to first grade, where he killed a classmate.
docs.abstract: Police say 6-year-old boy who fatally shot schoolmate in Mount Morris Township, Mich, was himself victim of neglect and abuse; say his father is in and out of prison and his mother is drug addict who admits exposing her children to marijuana on daily basis; say boy was sent to live with uncle in home neighbors say is filled with noise, drugs and guns; uncle, Sirmarcus Winfrey, is jailed on outstanding warrant for theft after authorities find stolen handgun and narcotics in his home; another man, who authorities say lived in home and brought stolen gun used in killing into home, turns himself in to police; authorities who questioned boy after killing say he does not seem to comprehend what happened and appeared nonchalant when interviewed by detectives; authorities say they heard that boy recently had quarrel with Kayla Renee Rolland, girl he shot to death; photos (M)

headline.main: A Life of Guns, Drugs and Now, Killing, All at 6

docs.snippet: Dance Connecticut got a rocky start to life, founded as it was on the ashes of the popular Hartford Ballet, which disbanded last year. But the new troupe chose wisely for its first major production. It would be tempting to describe Jean Grand-Mait...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dance Connecticut got a rocky start to life, founded as it was on the ashes of the popular Hartford Ballet, which disbanded last year. But the new troupe chose wisely for its first major production. It would be tempting to describe Jean Grand-Maitre's opening premiere as ''Romeo and Juliet Lite.'' But light and sweet is a much better description. Mr. Grand-Maitre has rooted his ''Romeo and Juliet,'' performed on Saturday afternoon in the handsome theater called the Bushnell, in the clear, lyrical classicism and American youthfulness that have distinguished the Hartford Ballet and Dance Connecticut. The sets have been streamlined and stylized, and the Prokofiev score has been softened imaginatively with whispered calls of ''Romeo'' and ''Juliet'' and murmured phrases from the play that accompany the taped music.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Dunning reviews concert by Dance Connecticut at Bushnell theater in Hartford; photo (M)

headline.main: Young Lovers for a Young Company

docs.snippet: Fashion Meets Politics      Early on in the Clinton presidency, Ellen Mullman, a sales executive for Tamotsu, a Japanese designer based in New York, received a call from the White House. Ms. Mullman did not make the immediate association most peop...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fashion Meets Politics Early on in the Clinton presidency, Ellen Mullman, a sales executive for Tamotsu, a Japanese designer based in New York, received a call from the White House. Ms. Mullman did not make the immediate association most people do when they hear the words ''White'' and ''House'' in conjunction, which is to say, she did not call to mind the residential complex that is host to the nation's highest profile Easter egg hunt. Instead, Ms. Mullman said, she thought to herself, ''That's a dumb name for a store.'' The White House -- the one in which no clothes are sold -- was calling because Hillary Rodham Clinton wanted to buy some Tamotsu pants and skirts. ''We're an unknown name, we're not a Calvin Klein name,'' Ms. Mullman said. One of Mrs. Clinton's secretaries got on the phone with Ms. Mullman and asked her to send some of the conservative separates the designer is known for to Washington, in size 8. ''I was thinking, 'Liar,' '' Ms. Mullman recalled, when she heard the first lady's size. Ms. Mullman sent down some 10's and ''they all came back pinned,'' she said. ''She's truly an 8.''
docs.abstract: Front Row column on Hillary Rodham Clinton becoming customer of Tamotsu, a Japanese designer based in New York (M)

headline.main: Front Row; Fashion and politics: wherein Hillary Clinton's dress size is revealed Fashion and the movies: Oscar gets a stylist.

docs.snippet: The first woman to become mayor of Mexico City, Rosario Robles Berlanga, liked what she heard from her police chief over her cellular phone. She snapped it shut and broke into one of her broad, beaming smiles.    A day earlier, 2,000 policemen, in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The first woman to become mayor of Mexico City, Rosario Robles Berlanga, liked what she heard from her police chief over her cellular phone. She snapped it shut and broke into one of her broad, beaming smiles. A day earlier, 2,000 policemen, in a wildcat protest, blocked several avenues and created a traffic catastrophe downtown. The rampage started over a bonus the city said it had accidentally failed to pay, but it continued even after cashiers rushed to the mutinous precinct to make amends.
docs.abstract: Rosario Robles Berlanga, first woman to become mayor of Mexico City, has surprised beleaguered residents of capital city by convincingly and cheerfully taking command of one of most chaotic metropolises in world during first five months in office; her rise has been boom for women in Mexican politics; photo (M)

headline.main: Mexico City Journal; Tough, Cheerful Mayor Wins Hearts

docs.snippet: Oscar De La Hoya had promised to be more aggressive and seek the knockout, after a disappointing loss to Felix Trinidad last Sept. 18. Against Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, De La Hoya was not any more aggressive than he...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya had promised to be more aggressive and seek the knockout, after a disappointing loss to Felix Trinidad last Sept. 18. Against Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, De La Hoya was not any more aggressive than he had been in the past, but he did seek the knockout. De La Hoya leveled Coley, who was counted out at exactly three minutes of the seventh round to put an end to a fight in which Coley was clearly overmatched. De La Hoya decked Coley with a wicked left hook to the body, and Referee Wayne Kelly counted out Coley as he kneeled down trying to catch his breath.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya's seventh-round knockout of Derrell Coley discussed (M)

headline.main: De La Hoya Able to Keep One of His Two Promises

docs.snippet: Matt Galloway talks in sporadic, sometimes emotional bursts. His hands fly around. His body tries to keep up. At least that is how Stephen Belber portrayed him onstage.    ''I questioned that at first,'' the real Mr. Galloway said after watching '...
docs.lead_paragraph: Matt Galloway talks in sporadic, sometimes emotional bursts. His hands fly around. His body tries to keep up. At least that is how Stephen Belber portrayed him onstage. ''I questioned that at first,'' the real Mr. Galloway said after watching ''The Laramie Project,'' a new play by Moises Kaufman of the New York-based Tectonic Theater Project, which had its premiere here on Saturday night. ''But I guess I really do talk like that. It was pretty accurate.''
docs.abstract: Article on The Laramie Project, new play by Moises Kaufman of New York-based Tectonic Theater Project about Laramie, Wyo, murder of gay University of Wyoming student Matthew Shepard by two local roofers in 1999; play is based on court records, personal journals and 200 interviews conducted in Laramie by Kaufman, his writers and actors (M)

headline.main: Turning a Murder Case Into a Theatrical Event

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Saving the Oscar Show From Itself'' (Arts pages, Feb. 23) reports that the producers of this year's Academy Award show have ''cut out all the dance numbers'' and that ''unhappy choreographers have sent protest letters.'' Indeed...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Saving the Oscar Show From Itself'' (Arts pages, Feb. 23) reports that the producers of this year's Academy Award show have ''cut out all the dance numbers'' and that ''unhappy choreographers have sent protest letters.'' Indeed. How would the members of other film crafts feel if it were announced that there would be no sound? No costumes? No script? Supplying dance for live production numbers in the ceremony was the last tie to Oscar that choreographers had. Academy Awards were bestowed for best dance direction from 1935 to 1937, and then the category was eliminated. Over the years the academy feebly tried to acknowledge dance input by giving special awards to Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly, Jerome Robbins, Onna White, Michael Kidd and Stanley Donen.
docs.abstract: Letter from Larry Billman, president, Academy of Dance on Film, scores decision by producers of this year's Academy Award show to cut out all dance numbers (Feb 23 article); drawing (S)

headline.main: Gotta Dance! But Oscar Won't Let Us

docs.snippet: IN the frigid early-morning hours of Oct. 7, 1998, a bicyclist found the beaten and bloodied body of a 21-year-old college student tied to a buck-rail fence in a remote field outside Laramie, Wyo. Matthew Shepard was not dead yet, but within five ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the frigid early-morning hours of Oct. 7, 1998, a bicyclist found the beaten and bloodied body of a 21-year-old college student tied to a buck-rail fence in a remote field outside Laramie, Wyo. Matthew Shepard was not dead yet, but within five days he would be. Two local roofers about the same age as the victim were arrested and charged with a murder they eventually confessed to committing. Learning that Mr. Shepard was gay, they had lured him out of a downtown bar, robbed him of $20, then beat him into unconsciousness with the butt end of a handgun. They left him to die on the prairie because they did not know what else to do with him. To avoid the death penalty, each pleaded guilty in exchange for a sentence of life in prison with no chance for parole.
docs.abstract: Moises Kaufman, artistic director of Tectonic Theater Project in New York, has created play, The Laramie Project, crafted from tape-recorded interviews with 200 residents of Laramie, Wyo, where Matthew Shepard was beaten to death for being homosexual; calls play attempt to understand how ordinary people might be affected by such extraordinary event; play is production of Denver Center Theater Co in association with Tectonic; photo (M)

headline.main: A Death in Laramie, Reimagined as Drama

docs.snippet: Q: During the recent fashion week in New York, your group got a lot of attention for some very high-profile anti-fur protests, like throwing pies in designers' faces. What's in those pies, anyway?    It depends. When we pied a rodeo queen, it was ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Q: During the recent fashion week in New York, your group got a lot of attention for some very high-profile anti-fur protests, like throwing pies in designers' faces. What's in those pies, anyway? It depends. When we pied a rodeo queen, it was a cow pie, so that was a brown soy-milk-and-chocolate-pudding pie with vegan whipped cream on top. We make all the pies vegan. At the Michael Kors event, his pie got runny because it had been sitting in the camera bag for an hour and a half. We heard some of the press people debating afterward what was in the pie, was it moisturizer? But it was runny vegan Hip Whip.
docs.abstract: Interview with Raeleann Smith, head of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, justifying her group's high-profile anti-fur protests, like throwing pies in designers' faces at recent fashion week in New York; photo (M)

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 2-27-00: Questions for RaeLeann Smith; How to Win Friends And Alienate People

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PEOPLE FOR THE ETHICAL TREATMENT OF ANIMALS
